lcn.p: Remember Yoda's observation about Luke Skywalker - how he was always obsessed, fixated on the future that he was headed toward to the point of neglecting the moment that he was in at the present. Even in his dealings up to that point with the Jedi Master on Degobah, Luke's fixation on where he was off to was an issue --- constantly obsessed with his search for the mysterious Yoda to the point that it never occurred to him to ask the little green fellow in front of him what his name was.

Had Luke bothered to ask the little green creature his name -- he might have answered right there and then that his name was "Yoda", and Luke would have realized that he had found the Jedi Master he sought.

Being obsessed with where you are going to the point of total neglect of the moment you are in right there and then can cause all kinds of disasters -- from not knowing when you have reached your destination - to not seeing the clearest path to your destination even if you haven't reached it.

Fixation on the future, of course, is not to be confused with proper, due regard for the future. Nor should anyone disregard the potential future consequences of one's actions in the name of not being fixated on the future. Rather, the admonition against fixation on the future means seeing the future for what it is - while recognizing that the immediate actions one is to take are not in the future any more than they are in the past, but rather, they are in the present moment.

It also means that the present moment is the environment that one must interact with right now. Even if your present actions affect the environment of the future -- it will not be until later that you actually interact with that future environment. Therefore, let no future planning interfere with awareness of the present - and let it not interfere with focusing on one's present actions either.
If you fail to heed this admonition, you run increased risk of even allowing your obsession of the future to paralyze your actions in the present moment!

Being present in the moment also involves barriers that must be set with the past. We must always learn from our past -- both from our triumphs and from our failures -- both from our mistakes and from times that we made the right move. However, regret and loathing about the past are a waste of energy at best -- and they have the potential of being the seed of great darkness, which is much worse.
Learn from the past -- but move on from it. The past is gone. The present moment is now here -- and you must attend to it now before it, too, slips into the realm of the past.

Fuming, crying, or otherwise harming your soul over the past, are you? Pause then and remind yourself that the past can no longer be changed. The future is in flux. The past, however, is now only a source of lessons. Let not baggage from the past be the basis for you damaging your soul in the present.
The past is gone. For right now, only the present is here.

So when concern of the future overwhelms you -- be present in the moment. When anger or regret regarding the past that can no longer change seizes you -- be present in the moment. And when your fears and worries paralyze you from what you need to do immediately -- be present in the moment.
Peg this onto the third verse of the Jedi Mantra: "There is no passion, there is serenity."
